column4: How can I determine what wireless driver I am using for a given card?
try a 'dmesg | grep INTERFACE_NAME'
I see "NDIS driver: oem32" in one of the lines. Can I assume the driver name is oem32?
uh.. yikes... well, i think that implies that your driver is something called ndiswrapper, which wraps windows drivers... so, presumably, it's ndiswrapper wrapping oem32.inf, or something like that.
So there's no way to tell? Or were you being sarcastic?
i'm sure there's a way to tell, but i don't use ndiswrapper, so i don't know it off the top of my head.
OK, thanks for the help
try "ndiswrapper -l" in a terminal
Among other things "oem32 : driver installed"
try 'locate oem32'
http://paste.ubuntu-nl.org/37275/
ar5523.sys looks interesting
lmao at "/home/nmajik/Desktop/New WIFI junk. Delete if working/oem32.inf"
After pasting that, I thought you might be amused
Well, the stuff in Desktop/New\ WIFI* is probably what you installed.
that makes it sound as though you intentionally installed the 'oem32.inf' driver using ndiswrapper from that directory.
Absolutely, I just don't know what ubuntu is calling it now
what do you mean, what ubuntu is calling it?  what do you think you need to know the driver name for?  :)
I'm trying to set up kismet but I'm getting the feeling I might have to go with a different driver
I'm not encouraged though... my card sounds like a very uncommon chipset
Well, not "very"
well, you probably don't need to tell kismet the name of the underlying driver ndiswrapper is using.  if you get it working, it will be by using the 'ndiswrapper' driver, or something like that.  :)
Well, I guess that ends my search. Thanks for your help
no problem.
